title: Tariffs Are a Tax on the Future

Tariffs Are a Tax on the Future

Why the U.S. Is Betting Against Global Prosperity

Kenji

I
magine a world where your local grocery store suddenly charges you double for oranges — just because they came from the neighboring town. Not because the quality changed, not because of a shortage, just because.

Now scale that decision across thousands of products and billions in trade, and you understand the strange logic behind modern tariffs.

The United States has chosen this path again, raising tariffs dramatically on a wide range of goods. This is being framed as fairness. In reality, it’s friction—unnecessary, self-inflicted, and expensive.

Let’s be clear: tariffs are not just taxes on foreign countries. They are taxes on your consumption, your supply chain, your future.

The Hidden Cost of Protectionism

The popular defense of tariffs is simple: “They protect local jobs.”

That’s appealing, especially when people feel their economies are vulnerable. But the evidence tells a different story.

Tariffs raise prices. They slow down trade. They disrupt investment. And in the end, they often hurt the very workers they’re supposed to protect.

Why are these numbers so different? No one really knows. The data used to justify them is, at best, questionable. South Korea and Malaysia were accused of applying 50% tariffs on U.S. goods — but trade records don’t support that.

Tariffs Don’t Solve Global Problems

The world economy isn’t a boxing ring where one side wins and the other loses. It’s a network — interconnected, interdependent, and built on cooperation. When tariffs go up in one country, costs ripple outward. Investment freezes. Prices rise. Innovation slows.

Asia-Pacific economies are particularly exposed. These are manufacturing-driven countries, deeply embedded in supply chains that stretch from factory floors in Vietnam to ports in California. When the U.S. imposes tariffs, these systems don’t just bend — they break.

And the damage doesn’t stop there:

Lessons from History

We’ve seen this movie before. The 1930 Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act worsened the Great Depression. Trade shrank, countries retaliated, and cooperation fell apart.

Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act - Wikipedia

Nicknames Hawley-Smoot Tariff, Smoot-Hawley Tariff Enacted by the 71st United States Congress Public law Pub. L. 71-361…

en.wikipedia.org

Today, we face different challenges—climate change, technological disruption, and geopolitical instability. Tariffs cannot fix these problems. In fact, they make cooperation harder.

When the U.S. sends the message that every trading partner is a threat, it creates a world where every country arms itself with trade barriers.

No one wins in that scenario — not even the strongest economies.

A Smarter Way Forward

We do have legitimate trade concerns.

But those should be handled through modern tools: negotiated agreements, transparent enforcement, shared standards.

Tariffs are a 19th-century solution to a 21st-century economy.

If we care about competitiveness, resilience, and long-term prosperity, the answer isn’t retreat — it’s reform.

The real risk of these tariffs isn’t that they will destroy trade overnight. It’s that they will quietly erode the foundation of global cooperation we’ve spent decades building.

Trade is not just about goods. It’s about trust.

And once that’s broken, no tariff can bring it back.
